articles.title: Thirteen hours by touch – inside one of the world's longest exam days
articles.summary: South Korea's national college entry exam is notoriously hard - but blind students face unique challenges.
articles.content:
Thirteen hours by touch – inside one of the world's longest exam days

5 hours ago Share Save Hyojung Kim BBC Korean Share Save

BBC/Hosu Lee Han Dong-hyun, a student at Seoul Hanbit School for the Blind, is among those who will take the "longest version" of the infamous Suneung exam

Every November, South Korea comes to a standstill for its infamous college entrance exam. Shops are shut, flights are delayed to reduce noise, and even the rhythm of the morning commute slows down for the students. By late afternoon, most test-takers walk out of school gates, exhaling with relief and embracing the family members waiting outside. But not everyone finishes at that hour. Even once darkness has fully settled and night has set in, some students are still in the exam room - finishing close to 10pm. They are the blind students, who often spend more than 12 hours taking the longest version of the Suneung.

On Thursday, more than 550,000 students across the country will sit for the Suneung - an abbreviation for College Scholastic Ability Test (CSAT) in Korean. It is the highest number of applicants in seven years. The test not only dictates whether people will be able to go to university, but can affect their job prospects, income, where they will live and even future relationships. Depending on their subject choices, students answer roughly 200 questions across Korean, mathematics, English, social or natural sciences, an additional foreign language, and Hanja (classical Chinese characters used in Korean). For most students, it is an eight-hour marathon of back-to-back exams. They begin the Suneung test at 08:40 and finish around 17:40. Blind students with severe visual impairments, however, are given 1.7 times the standard testing duration. This means that if they take the additional foreign language section, the exam can finish as late as 21:48 - nearly 13 hours after it began. There is no dinner break; the exam continues straight through. The physical bulk of the braille test papers also contributes to the length. When every sentence, symbol and diagram is converted into braille, each test booklet becomes six to nine times thicker than the standard equivalent.

BBC/Hosu Lee The constant friction from reading braille for hours straight can make students' hands sore

At Seoul Hanbit School for the Blind, 18-year-old Han Donghyun is among the students who will take the longest version of the Suneung this year. Last year, there were 111 blind test-takers nationwide - 99 with low vision and 12 with severe visual impairments like Dong-hyun - according to data from the Ministry of Education and the Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation. Dong-hyun was born completely blind and cannot distinguish light. When the BBC met him at his school on 7 November, his fingers moved quickly across a braille practice booklet of past exam questions. With just a week left before the test, he was focused on managing his stamina and condition. Dong-hyun will take the exam using braille test papers and a screen-reading computer. "It's really exhausting because the exam is so long," he said. "But there's no special trick. I just follow my study schedule and try to manage my condition. That's the only way."

Dong-hyun said the Korean language section is particularly difficult for him. A standard test booklet for that section is about 16 pages - but the braille version is roughly 100 pages long. Even with screen-reading software, spoken information disappears as soon as it is heard, unlike text that can be seen and re-read. Dong-hyun has to hold the details in his memory as he goes. The mathematics section is no easier. He must interpret complex graphs and tables that have been converted into braille, using only his fingertips. Still, he noted that things are better than they used to be. In the past, students had to do almost all calculations in their heads. But since 2016, blind test-takers have been allowed to use a braille notetaker, known as Hansone. "Just like sighted students write out their calculations in pencil, we enter them in braille on the Hansone to follow the steps," he said.

BBC/Hosu Lee Students like Oh Jeong-won must use braille display devices during the exam

Another student at Hanbit School for the Blind, 18-year-old Oh Jeong-won, who will also sit the Suneung this year, said the late afternoon is "the hardest point" of the day. "Up until lunch, it's manageable," he said. "But around 4 or 5pm, after English and before Korean History, that's when it gets really tough. "There's no dinner break," he explained. "We're solving problems during the time we would normally eat, so it feels even more exhausting. Still, I keep going because I know there will be a sense of accomplishment at the end." For Jeong-won, the fatigue is compounded by the need to stay intensely focused with both his hands and his hearing. "When I'm reading the braille with my fingers and also taking in information through audio, it feels much more tiring than it does for sighted students," he said. But the students say that the length of the exam and the long study hours are not the hardest part. What is most challenging is access to study materials. Popular textbooks and online lectures that sighted students rely on are often out of reach. There are very few braille versions, and converting materials into audio requires having text files - which are difficult to obtain. In many cases, someone has to manually type out entire workbooks to make them usable. Online lectures also pose difficulties, as many instructors explain concepts using visual notes, diagrams and graphics on screen, which cannot be followed through audio alone.

BBC/Hosu Lee Ahead of the Suneung exam, Han Dong-hyun and Oh Jeong-won solve past questions using a screen reader and braille

One of the most significant barriers, however, is the delay in receiving braille versions of the state-produced EBS preparation books - a core set of materials closely linked to the national exam. Because of this delay, blind students often receive the materials months later than others. "Sighted students get their EBS books between January and March and study them for the whole year," said Jeong-won. "We receive the braille files only around August or September, when the exam is just a few months away." Dong-hyun shared the same concern. "The braille materials weren't completed until less than 90 days before the exam," he said. "I kept wishing the publication process could be faster." The National Institute of Special Education, which produces the braille version of EBS exam materials, told the BBC that the process takes at least three months for each book because it must follow relevant guidelines. The institute added that it is "making various efforts to ensure that blind students can study without disruption, such as producing and providing the materials in separate volumes." The Korean Blind Union said it has long raised this issue with authorities, and plans to file a constitutional petition demanding greater accessibility to braille versions of all textbooks.

BBC/Hosu Lee For blind students, the Suneung exam can last for more than 12 hours

It sheds light on ongoing accessibility issues and efforts to improve educational equity for visually impaired students, which has broad societal significance and positive real-world impact on human rights and inclusion.
articles.personality_title: Blind students face a 13-hour marathon in South Korea’s toughest exam
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Every year in South Korea, millions of students take a very important test called the Suneung. This exam helps decide which university they can attend and can influence their future jobs and lives. For most students, the exam lasts about eight hours. But for blind students, it can take much longer.

**What happened**
This year, more than 550,000 students took the Suneung exam. Blind students, like 18-year-olds Han Dong-hyun and Oh Jeong-won, spend nearly 13 hours taking the test because they need extra time and use braille papers. The braille test booklets are much thicker than normal ones because every word and symbol is in braille. There is no dinner break during the exam, so the students work straight through the day until nearly 10pm.

**Impact**
These long hours show the unique challenges blind students face. They must read complicated information by touch and remember details without being able to see or re-read material easily. Although tools like braille notetakers help, blind students still struggle with limited access to study materials. They often get important preparation books much later than other students, making it harder to prepare. This story highlights the efforts to make education fairer for blind students, while also showing where improvements are still needed.

**What's next step**
Groups representing blind people are pushing the government to provide braille textbooks earlier and improve access to study resources. The National Institute of Special Education is trying to speed up producing braille materials by breaking books into smaller parts. These changes aim to give blind students more equal chances in their education and future careers.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Blind students in South Korea face a demanding 13-hour exam day, revealing both progress and ongoing challenges in making education accessible to all.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des étudiants aveugles affrontent un marathon de 13 heures lors de l’examen le plus difficile de Corée du Sud
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Chaque année en Corée du Sud, des millions d’étudiants passent un examen très important appelé Suneung. Ce test détermine à quelle université ils peuvent aller et influence leur avenir professionnel et personnel. Pour la plupart, l’examen dure environ huit heures. Mais pour les étudiants aveugles, cela prend beaucoup plus de temps.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Cette année, plus de 550 000 étudiants ont passé le Suneung. Les étudiants aveugles, comme Han Dong-hyun et Oh Jeong-won, âgés de 18 ans, passent près de 13 heures à passer le test car ils ont besoin de plus de temps et utilisent des papiers en braille. Les livrets de test en braille sont beaucoup plus épais que les livrets normaux car chaque mot et symbole est en braille. Il n’y a pas de pause dîner, donc les étudiants travaillent sans interruption jusqu’à presque 22 heures.

**Impact**
Ces longues heures montrent les défis uniques auxquels font face les étudiants aveugles. Ils doivent lire des informations compliquées au toucher et retenir les détails sans pouvoir voir ou relire facilement. Même si des outils comme les blocs-notes en braille aident, les étudiants aveugles ont encore un accès limité aux matériaux d’étude. Ils reçoivent souvent les livres de préparation importants bien plus tard que les autres, ce qui complique leur préparation. Cette histoire met en lumière les efforts pour rendre l’éducation plus équitable pour les aveugles, tout en montrant où des améliorations sont encore nécessaires.

**Prochaine étape**
Les associations représentant les aveugles demandent au gouvernement de fournir les manuels en braille plus tôt et d’améliorer l’accès aux ressources d’étude. L’Institut national d’éducation spécialisée essaie d’accélérer la production des matériaux en braille en divisant les livres en parties plus petites. Ces changements visent à offrir aux étudiants aveugles des chances plus égales dans leurs études et leur avenir professionnel.

**Résumé en une phrase**
Les étudiants aveugles en Corée du Sud affrontent une journée d’examen de 13 heures, révélant à la fois des progrès et des défis persistants pour rendre l’éducation accessible à tous.

articles.title: Trial of Ex-Congolese Warlord Important Step for Justice
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Roger Lumbala Tshitenga, a former Congolese rebel leader and government minister, in Kampala, Uganda, February 6, 2013.
                    © 2013 Isaac Kasamani/AFP via Getty Images 
          
    


  
The trial of Roger Lumbala Tshitenga, a former rebel leader and former minister in the Democratic Republic of Congo, begins on Wednesday, November 12, 2025, before the Paris Criminal Court. Lumbala is charged with crimes against humanity allegedly committed in North Kivu and Ituri provinces between 2002 and 2003, including summary executions, torture and other inhuman treatment, rape, pillages, and enslavement, including sexual slavery.French authorities arrested Lumbala in Paris in December 2020 and indicted him in November 2023 as a matter of universal jurisdiction. Under this legal principle, states can investigate and prosecute those responsible for grave crimes regardless of where they were committed or the nationality of the suspects or their victims.This is the first universal jurisdiction trial for atrocities committed in Congo by a Congolese national, an important step for justice and a testament to the perseverance of victims and survivors.Congo today remains embroiled in a conflict that has spanned over 30 years. Fighting between August 1998 and July 2003 involved the Congolese government against the Congolese Rally for Democracy (RCD) armed group and several national armed forces, including Rwanda, Uganda, and Burundi. Lumbala founded and led the Congolese Rally for Democracy-National (RCD-National), an armed group that Uganda supported to fight against the Congolese government, which had its own allies in a war that left over one million dead.Lumbala, 67, is accused of complicity in crimes against humanity during “Effacer le tableau” (“Erase the board”), a military operation carried out by the RCD-National between October 2002 and January 2003 to capture the resource-rich territory of Beni in North Kivu province.Lumbala’s trial is a stark reminder of the persistent impunity for atrocities in Congo; for more than three decades, the near absence of accountability has contributed to recurrent cycles of abuse. Governments should support and strengthen justice efforts for Congo, both domestic and international, and they should continue to pursue cases under universal jurisdiction to bolster victims’ access to justice.
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Roger Lumbala Tshitenga, a former Congolese rebel leader and government minister, in Kampala, Uganda, February 6, 2013. © 2013 Isaac Kasamani/AFP via Getty Images

The trial of Roger Lumbala Tshitenga, a former rebel leader and former minister in the Democratic Republic of Congo, begins on Wednesday, November 12, 2025, before the Paris Criminal Court. Lumbala is charged with crimes against humanity allegedly committed in North Kivu and Ituri provinces between 2002 and 2003, including summary executions, torture and other inhuman treatment, rape, pillages, and enslavement, including sexual slavery.

French authorities arrested Lumbala in Paris in December 2020 and indicted him in November 2023 as a matter of universal jurisdiction. Under this legal principle, states can investigate and prosecute those responsible for grave crimes regardless of where they were committed or the nationality of the suspects or their victims.

This is the first universal jurisdiction trial for atrocities committed in Congo by a Congolese national, an important step for justice and a testament to the perseverance of victims and survivors.

Congo today remains embroiled in a conflict that has spanned over 30 years. Fighting between August 1998 and July 2003 involved the Congolese government against the Congolese Rally for Democracy (RCD) armed group and several national armed forces, including Rwanda, Uganda, and Burundi. Lumbala founded and led the Congolese Rally for Democracy-National (RCD-National), an armed group that Uganda supported to fight against the Congolese government, which had its own allies in a war that left over one million dead.

Lumbala, 67, is accused of complicity in crimes against humanity during “Effacer le tableau” (“Erase the board”), a military operation carried out by the RCD-National between October 2002 and January 2003 to capture the resource-rich territory of Beni in North Kivu province.

Lumbala’s trial is a stark reminder of the persistent impunity for atrocities in Congo; for more than three decades, the near absence of accountability has contributed to recurrent cycles of abuse. Governments should support and strengthen justice efforts for Congo, both domestic and international, and they should continue to pursue cases under universal jurisdiction to bolster victims’ access to justice.
articles.reasoning: The trial of a former Congolese warlord under universal jurisdiction marks a significant step toward justice for crimes against humanity, addressing long-standing impunity and supporting victims' access to justice. This has broad significance for human rights and accountability in conflict zones.
articles.personality_title: Trial of Former Congolese Rebel Leader Opens in Paris for Crimes Against Humanity
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Roger Lumbala Tshitenga was a rebel leader and government minister in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Between 2002 and 2003, violent conflicts in the DRC involved many armed groups and foreign armies, causing millions of deaths. Lumbala led one such group, the Congolese Rally for Democracy-National (RCD-National), which fought in the North Kivu region.

**What happened** – On November 12, 2025, Roger Lumbala’s trial began in Paris. He faces charges of crimes against humanity, including killings, torture, rape, and enslavement during a military operation called “Effacer le tableau” in 2002-2003. France arrested him in 2020 and charged him under universal jurisdiction, a law allowing countries to prosecute serious crimes no matter where they happened.

**Impact** – This is the first time a Congolese national is being tried in France under universal jurisdiction for crimes committed in Congo. It shows that justice can reach people accused of serious crimes even if their home country cannot or will not act. The trial also recognizes the suffering of victims and challenges the history of impunity in Congo’s long conflict.

**What's next step** – The court will hear evidence and testimonies to decide Lumbala’s guilt or innocence. The trial could encourage other countries to use universal jurisdiction for similar cases. It may also inspire stronger support for justice efforts inside Congo and provide hope for survivors seeking accountability.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The trial of Roger Lumbala in Paris marks an important moment for justice by holding a former Congolese rebel leader accountable for serious crimes committed during a brutal conflict.
articles.personality_title_fr: Procès à Paris d'un ancien chef rebelle congolais pour crimes contre l'humanité
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Roger Lumbala Tshitenga était un chef rebelle et ministre dans la République démocratique du Congo (RDC). Entre 2002 et 2003, des conflits violents ont impliqué plusieurs groupes armés et armées étrangères, causant des millions de morts. Lumbala dirigeait un groupe appelé Rassemblement congolais pour la démocratie-National (RCD-National) qui combattait dans la région du Nord-Kivu.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 12 novembre 2025, le procès de Roger Lumbala a commencé à Paris. Il est accusé de crimes contre l'humanité, notamment des exécutions, tortures, viols et esclavage lors d'une opération militaire nommée « Effacer le tableau » entre 2002 et 2003. La France l’a arrêté en 2020 et inculpé sous la juridiction universelle, une loi qui permet de juger des crimes graves partout dans le monde.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois qu’un Congolais est jugé en France sous cette juridiction pour des crimes commis au Congo. Cela montre que la justice peut atteindre des personnes accusées même si leur pays d’origine ne le fait pas. Ce procès reconnaît aussi la souffrance des victimes et remet en cause l’impunité historique au Congo.

**Prochaine étape** – Le tribunal écoutera les preuves et témoignages pour décider de la culpabilité ou non de Lumbala. Ce procès pourrait encourager d’autres pays à utiliser la juridiction universelle. Il pourrait aussi renforcer les efforts de justice au Congo et donner de l’espoir aux survivants.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Le procès de Roger Lumbala à Paris est un moment important pour la justice en tenant un ancien chef rebelle congolais responsable de graves crimes commis pendant un conflit brutal.
articles.personality_title_es: Juicio en París a exlíder rebelde congoleño por crímenes de lesa humanidad
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Roger Lumbala Tshitenga fue un líder rebelde y ministro en la República Democrática del Congo (RDC). Entre 2002 y 2003, hubo conflictos violentos que involucraron a varios grupos armados y ejércitos extranjeros, causando millones de muertes. Lumbala dirigió un grupo llamado Rally Congoleño por la Democracia-Nacional (RCD-Nacional) que luchó en la región de Kivu Norte.

**Qué pasó** – El 12 de noviembre de 2025 comenzó el juicio de Roger Lumbala en París. Está acusado de crímenes de lesa humanidad, incluyendo ejecuciones, torturas, violaciones y esclavitud durante una operación militar llamada “Borrar el tablero” entre 2002 y 2003. Francia lo arrestó en 2020 y lo acusó bajo la jurisdicción universal, una ley que permite juzgar crímenes graves sin importar dónde ocurrieron.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que un nacional congoleño es juzgado en Francia bajo esta jurisdicción por crímenes cometidos en el Congo. Esto demuestra que la justicia puede llegar a personas acusadas incluso si su país no actúa. El juicio también reconoce el sufrimiento de las víctimas y desafía la impunidad en el conflicto del Congo.

**Próximo paso** – El tribunal escuchará pruebas y testimonios para decidir si Lumbala es culpable o no. El juicio podría inspirar a otros países a usar la jurisdicción universal y fortalecer los esfuerzos de justicia dentro del Congo, dando esperanza a los sobrevivientes.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El juicio de Roger Lumbala en París representa un momento clave para la justicia al responsabilizar a un exlíder rebelde congoleño por graves crímenes cometidos durante un conflicto violento.

articles.title: Press release - Proxy voting for maternity reasons: press point with the President and rapporteur (Thursday 12.30 CET)
articles.summary: Following the vote on a legislative initiative to introduce a proxy voting option for late pregnancy and early motherhood, Parliament’s President and the rapporteur will speak to the media.Committee on Constitutional Affairs Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.content:
Under the proposed rule change, an MEP who is pregnant or has recently given birth may delegate her plenary vote to another MEP for up to three months before the estimated date of birth and six months after childbirth.

The legislative proposal will have to be submitted to the Council for unanimous approval by the member states. For the new rules to enter into force, all EU countries will have to approve them in line with their respective constitutional procedures.

Who: European Parliament President Roberta Metsola and rapporteur Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D, Spain).

When: Thursday 13 November, c. 12:30 CET.

Where: European Parliament in Brussels, outside the plenary chamber (Hemicycle), Paul-Henri Spaak building, 3rd floor.

How: Accredited journalists can join in person and are kindly requested to ask questions in English, since there will be no interpretation. The press point will be streamed live and become available on Parliament’s Multimedia Centre.
articles.reasoning: The legislative initiative to allow proxy voting for MEPs during late pregnancy and early motherhood represents a significant policy change that supports gender equality and work-life balance in political representation. This change has broad societal implications by enabling better participation of women in politics during critical life stages, promoting inclusivity and fairness. The article provides sufficient context about the proposal, its scope, and the approval process, making it a substantive and meaningful development.
articles.personality_title: European Parliament proposes proxy voting for pregnant and new mother MEPs
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Women who are members of the European Parliament (MEPs) sometimes face challenges balancing their political work with pregnancy and early motherhood. Currently, they must attend sessions in person to vote, even during these demanding times.

**What happened** – The European Parliament has voted on a new rule that would allow MEPs who are in late pregnancy or have recently given birth to delegate their voting power to another MEP. This proxy voting can be used for up to three months before the baby is due and six months after birth. The Parliament’s President, Roberta Metsola, and the rapporteur, Juan Fernando López Aguilar, shared details about this change during a press event on November 13, 2025.

**Impact** – This rule change helps women in politics by making it easier to take care of their health and newborns without missing important votes. It supports gender equality by recognizing the special needs of pregnant and new mothers in a demanding job. If all EU member countries approve this rule, it will make political participation fairer and more inclusive.

**What's next step** – The proposal must be approved unanimously by all EU member states. Each country will review it according to their own laws before it can become official. Once approved, the new voting system will be put into practice across the European Parliament.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The European Parliament is working to support women MEPs by allowing proxy voting during late pregnancy and early motherhood, promoting fairness in political participation.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Parlement européen propose le vote par procuration pour les députées enceintes et jeunes mamans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les femmes membres du Parlement européen (députées) rencontrent parfois des difficultés à concilier leur travail politique avec la grossesse et les premiers mois de maternité. Actuellement, elles doivent être présentes pour voter, même dans ces périodes exigeantes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le Parlement européen a voté une nouvelle règle permettant aux députées en fin de grossesse ou récemment devenues mères de déléguer leur droit de vote à un autre député. Ce vote par procuration pourra être utilisé jusqu’à trois mois avant la naissance prévue et jusqu’à six mois après l’accouchement. La présidente du Parlement, Roberta Metsola, et le rapporteur, Juan Fernando López Aguilar, ont présenté cette mesure lors d’un point presse le 13 novembre 2025.

**Impact** – Cette mesure facilite la vie des femmes en politique en leur permettant de prendre soin de leur santé et de leur nouveau-né sans manquer les votes importants. Elle soutient l’égalité des sexes en reconnaissant les besoins particuliers des femmes enceintes et jeunes mamans dans un travail exigeant. Si tous les États membres approuvent cette règle, elle rendra la participation politique plus juste et inclusive.

**Prochaine étape** – La proposition doit être approuvée à l’unanimité par tous les États membres de l’UE. Chaque pays examinera la mesure selon ses propres lois avant qu’elle puisse devenir officielle. Une fois approuvée, cette nouvelle façon de voter sera appliquée dans tout le Parlement européen.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Le Parlement européen soutient les députées en permettant le vote par procuration pendant la fin de grossesse et la maternité, pour une participation politique plus équitable.
articles.personality_title_es: El Parlamento Europeo propone voto por delegación para diputadas embarazadas y madres recientes
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las mujeres que son diputadas en el Parlamento Europeo a veces enfrentan dificultades para combinar su trabajo político con el embarazo y la maternidad temprana. Actualmente, deben asistir en persona para votar, incluso en estas etapas exigentes.

**Qué pasó** – El Parlamento Europeo votó una nueva norma que permitirá a las diputadas en etapa avanzada de embarazo o que acaban de tener un bebé delegar su voto a otro diputado. Este voto por delegación se podrá usar hasta tres meses antes de la fecha prevista de parto y hasta seis meses después del nacimiento. La presidenta del Parlamento, Roberta Metsola, y el ponente, Juan Fernando López Aguilar, explicaron esta medida durante una rueda de prensa el 13 de noviembre de 2025.

**Impacto** – Esta regla ayuda a las mujeres en la política permitiéndoles cuidar su salud y a sus bebés sin perder votos importantes. Apoya la igualdad de género al reconocer las necesidades especiales de las madres embarazadas y recientes en un trabajo exigente. Si todos los países de la UE aprueban esta norma, hará que la participación política sea más justa e inclusiva.

**Próximo paso** – La propuesta debe ser aprobada por unanimidad por todos los países miembros de la UE. Cada país la revisará según sus propias leyes antes de que pueda entrar en vigor. Una vez aprobada, el nuevo sistema de votación se implementará en todo el Parlamento Europeo.

**Frase resumen** – El Parlamento Europeo busca apoyar a las diputadas permitiendo el voto por delegación durante el embarazo avanzado y la maternidad temprana, promoviendo la equidad en la participación política.
